qas.question: Who was the ruler of Valencia in 138 BC?
How many Romans lived in Valencia in 138 BC?
What road crossed Valencia's island in Roman times?
What is now located at the former centre of Valencia?
In Roman times, what two roads met at Valencia's centre?

answers.text: Cardo Maximus and the Decumanus Maximus

context: About <a1_0>two thousand<a1_0/> Roman colonists were settled there in 138 BC during the rule of consul <a0_0>Decimus Junius Brutus Galaico<a0_0/>. The Roman historian Florus says that Brutus transferred the soldiers who had fought under him to that province. This was a typical Roman city in its conception, as it was located in a strategic location near the sea on a river island crossed by the <a2_0>Via Augusta<a2_0/>, the imperial road that connected the province to Rome, the capital of the empire. The centre of the city was located in the present-day neighbourhood of the <a3_0>Plaza de la Virgen<a3_0/>. Here was the forum and the crossing of the <a4_0>Cardo Maximus and the Decumanus Maximus<a4_0/>, which remain the two main axes of the city. The Cardo corresponds to the existing Calle de Salvador, Almoina, and the Decumanus corresponds to Calle de los Caballeros.
